specs/ussuri/copy-image-in-multiple-stor.message:
You need to be a bit more specific here about the problem.  This is the same as the second paragraph of the support-glance-multiple-backend spec.  Since that one's been approved, Cinder is on track to take advantage of Glance multiple stores via the volume-type.  What you need to say here is that volume-type store specification is nice, but it doesn't allow for co-location (unless the image was already in the glance store defined by that volume-type).  Also, it depends on the operator configuring the volume-type extra-specs to define a preferred Glance store; if the operator doesn't take this step, all uploads go to the default Glance store.

Also mention somewhere that the way Cinder gets the store_id from the volume-type extra-specs to Glance is via the 'x-image-meta-store' header.
s/when/if the operator has not defined a glance store in the volume-type extra specs, the/

OK, I get it now.  The issue is that with "edge" configurations, operators will want to have images stored in multiple stores in order to get the image as close as possible to the place(s) it will be consumed.  Uploading to the default store, or even to the volume-type-defined store, will only put the image in one store, and Glance doesn't have sufficient information (since this is a brand-new image) about where else the image should go.  If this uploaded volume has initially been created from an image, Glance would like to put the new image in all the same stores as the original image.
You want to be clear here that this is already existing functionality.  Maybe, "When a volume is created from an image, Cinder currently stores the image_uuid in the volume_image_metadata."
you can say image_uuid here (that's what it's stored as)

We don't need to know what Glance is going to do for the purposes of this spec.  I suggest "can identify the store(s) in which the original image is located"--it's up to Glance to do whatever it wants with this info.  The key thing is to get the info to Glance.

I think this should be stated solely in Glance terms, because you are stating an Image API v2 contract here.  Something like "If a volume is created from an image and Cinder passes both the 'x-image-meta-store' and 'x-openstack-base-image-ref' headers, Glance will ignore the 'x-openstack-base-image-ref' header and will use the store_id specified in the 'x-image-meta-store' header."

This makes it clear to operators that if you define a store_id in the volume-type extra-specs, it will definitely be honored.  Hence, operators interested in image co-location will probably not define the extra-spec (or they won't define it for "edge" volume-types).
This seems to be the alternative of this feature i.e. Maybe should come in the Alternatives section

with specifying the store in the volume type also, we've no way of determining in which store(s) does the base image reside.
Also would require changing volume type extra specs multiple times to update the store_id

specs/ussuri/image-snapshot-co-location..message: when will this case occur? my thinking was if a volume is created from an image, it will always send image_id as header to glance during upload to image operation

this method informs the rest_client to tell the auth instance to remove the full path, including your /swift using a filter.

I searched for the use of the filter skip_path and API_version.  
I do not see api_version filter being used any more except in a unit test. 
The skip_path is used by the capabilities_Client and the tests test_healthcheck and test_crossdoamain. The test cases uses them to create rest calls outside a client on the fly. As long as they are there skip_path is need to function that way.
Can I suggest that we create a filter to skip_path_at_version that will remove the path from v1/* on
abc.com/swift/v1/api_version
abc.com/swift/

This would not need a config item and could have a full unit test for the change.

yes, skip_path removes the full path:
self.base_url changes from for example http://10.0.0.102:8080/v1/AUTH_20255b25960c4e2a8a1dea04e180ae29 to http://10.0.0.102:8080/
but then when the GET request is being made in rest_client.py "info" from line 26 is appended to the url, so the req_url is http://10.0.0.102:8080/info and the goal of this patch is to have the req_url equal to http://10.0.0.102:8080/swift/info. Therefore concatinating api_prefix ('' or 'swift') and 'info' on the line 26 should be enough.

if someone set api_prefix = 'swift/' in tempest.conf, then
the url will be swift//info, so better to strip "/" from api_prefix first.

This task will work with this change but i don't think it's actually fixing the issue completely(some other task below might also face the issue, like task on line 98) for which the patch is proposed. Testing the fix would also be difficult until and unless the issue is reproduced somehow.

so the issue appeared again and reported as bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1855429, as said in last comment, since this patch is fixing a transient issue, and all tasks in this play are related, fixing a single task will not help. The issue here is it's using /root cached from last run.

This patch might work for some of the tasks as it's setting ownership to ansible_user while creating directory but can miss some aspects as artifacts for this role are used by other roles too, so saying good to test it with the bug scenario that it fixes completely or not.

The more proper fix i think can be:-
1) either not relying on ansible_user_dir as base path
2) or fixing playbooks which caused this issue(usage of gather_facts: no or yes)

hm, we might call "setup" instead since it allows to take only a subset of facts, making it faster than the gather_fact... ?
But second one is probably better.
I do agree with you and I hope that soon we will have it tested with molecule. Until then, I needed to find a "progressive" approach: fix what was obvious.
unecessary but since I'm here why is " better than ' in this case? fine if its just preference but if there is a reason would be good to know about it.

a) single quote is common in English strings making it a less desired than double quote
b) be consistent with current code which uses ~90% double quote
c) python black defaults to " instead of '
d) me planning to add this to ansible-lint in the future ;)

Execution in 'MistralExecutionLister' does not refer to workflow-execution, but execution in general, 'MistralExecutionLister' is the base of List for Action Execution, Task Execution, and Workflow execution.
I moved the classes to executions.py, as for MistralExecutionLister I agree, but as it's not in the scope of this patch, we can do it on a sperate patch.

would it make sense to automatically include in the pipeline[1]? It would be transparent to ops and API users. with the benefit of already being available if users needed to use for a given account/container, plus no need for config changes.

[1] - https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/proxy/server.py#L66

My argument comes down to risk mitigation. There are two aspects I'm thinking about:

* Historically, we've had mixed results with auto-insertion. I'd maybe feel better about it if we had some kind of pipeline validation -- time for me to dust off https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635040/ I guess...
* Operators may (for whatever reason) want to keep the old-style unquoted etags cluster-wide -- and the only way to ensure that is by not having the middleware in the pipeline at all.

I would also like to see quoted etags become the default in the long-term. I'd like to believe it is possible if we follow a deprecation process. I think this middleware is just the first step. Maybe we could also state our intentions in the documentation and CHANGELOGs?

> I think this middleware is just the first step. Maybe we could also state our intentions in the documentation and CHANGELOGs?

Agreed -- the flow I see happening is:

* We have this middleware available as an option.
* We make it a recommended middleware, in the saio and sample proxy-server pipelines.
* We make it required, using auto-insertion.
* We change enable_by_default's default to true and start logging deprecation warnings.
* We remove enable_by_default as an option.

Func tests ought to pass with enable_by_default=True by step 2, 3 at the latest. I need to think about how best to communicate that roadmap to users, particularly considering how we won't necessarily get all the way to the end if there's enough push-back. I've got this feeling like we won't know until step 4 or so, when we get a bunch of bug reports about 422s :-/

I think I understand your point, but still don't see an argument as to why we shouldn't do it. My intent is to simplify operator/user configuration.

I would argue that we should be auto-inserting more middlewares, my hope is that it would minimize user mistakes in having to configure pipelines. The more middleware we make available, the higher chance of getting the pipeline order wrong.

In the end I believe I'm just extending my previous comment about not having this feature as a complete new middleware. I think the feature could have been added to an existing middleware.

It depends on what's the long-term strategy about etag. I would love that at some point the quoted etags become the default, but I don't see this happening because I'm not sure a lot of Swift libraries would start to handle it.

Given that I don't see quoted becomes the default at some point (or only in a very far future), I don't see a reason to auto-insert it in the pipeline (at least for now).

Historically, we've used pipeline auto-insertion to ensure smooth upgrades when

* pulling features out of the proxy-server app (dlo, versioned_writes, copy) or
* adding a new required middleware such that your cluster is (or should be considered) broken without it (catch_errors, gatekeeper, listing_formats)

and this doesn't really feel like either. Arguably, listing_formats *shouldn't* have gotten that treatment -- we could've just kept doing content-type checks in various middlewares and things should have mostly worked. Probably would've saved us from

* https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1758710,
* https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1806468, and
* https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1856303.
I suggest avoiding to use the `Meta` namespace. How about `X-Account-Rfc-Compliant-Etags` for client header and then store as sysmeta?

Really makes me wish we had a helper for translating client <-> sysmeta headers... and then there's the x-remove-account-rfc-compliant-etags case, too....

This is gonna need so many more tests :-(
nit: could we add this under swift param as "quoted_etags"?
I might get behind that idea if we did the auto-insertion thing, but I'm not sold on that yet.

whitebox_tempest_plugin/config.py.message:
So remember that whitebox is supposed to be not just Nova (though obviously right now in practice that's exactly what it is). It's why for services for example, we have the 'whitebox-nova-compute' config sections.

So we definitely need to make this option less Nova-assuming.

I think for now we can assume that any CI environment that runs this would have only one cell, so that simplifies things a bit.

One idea would be to put it in the 'whitebox-nova-compute' section, as the 'database-name' option.

Another would be to have a new generic 'nova' section, and call it 'cell1-database-name'.

A third would be to leave it in 'whitebox-database', but call it 'nova-cell1-db-name'.

I'm honestly not sure which one would be better, or if it even makes a differences. The third option would be the easiest to extend for other services, as we could just keep adding 'glance-db-name' or 'neutron-agent-db-name' options (names are examples pulled out of my *ahem*).
Unless there are some specific situations were additional unique parameters are needed to interact with the other db's outside of gateway, user, pass, etc.; I agree with your third suggestion.

 > parameters are needed to interact with the other db's outside of

As described, with 4 nodes you need 4 batches to avoid one batch taking half the nodes.
Should we not start new (or stopped) nodes before restarting existing ones? If we have 3 total but 2 are down, then restarting the one that is alive first will take out the cluster.
K-A requires now a healthy cluster to avoid any surprises. You should not be extending your cluster if it is almost broken. We produce an appropriate warning.
That's why lookup checks cluster's health and will proceed only if all is fine.

Do we explicitly check for that and fail?

It's not just when extending your cluster. If a container is down and 2 others are up, we could just bring up the one that's down first. Worse if two are down and one is up, we might take down the last container.
Haha, now I think I know why I grouped those. :D
Does it? It fails a host if its port is alive and it isn't synced. It might continue if the port is not alive, or if some nodes aren't synced but some are (due to any_errors_fatal: false).

ansible/roles/prune-images/defaults/main.message: We have docker_client_timeout. Does this need to be 300 or is the default of docker_client_timeout (120) ok?

I am confused as for what's the place of `TaskService` [1] and `Task` [2] resources?  Do we need to have them as sushy resource models?

`TaskMonitor` seems to be derived from `ResourceBase` what implies it's a resource. However I can't find it among Redfish schemas. Also, `TaskMonitor` implementation does not have any fields.

1. https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/TaskService.v1_1_3.json
2. https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/Task.v1_4_1.json

The TaskService and Task resources could certainly be added to the sushy resource models. But for the typical use case of a client needing to determine if a request that it has made was handled asynchronously, utilizing the Task Monitor opaque URL is sufficient and the preferred approach. 

As you noted, the Task Monitor does not have an associated resource (no JSON payload); all the information associated with the Task Monitor is provided via response headers (Location and Retry-After). I utilized the existing ResourceBase class because it was convenient to leverage its connection, access to response headers, etc. In a way, you can consider the Task Monitor a special case of a Redfish response that has an empty body payload.

If there is a better way to model the Task Monitor, I am certainly open to that.

Back to the Task and TaskService: These resources are more important for more generalized use cases where a client may need to locate and monitor tasks that may have been created by different clients.

We typically use TaskMonitor once we get HTTP 202 response. May be we could initialize `TaskMonitor` right from the response object instead of pulling pieces from it (e.g. retry-after') and passing alone?

The rationale is that we need to parse response object later on anyway (e.g.  `in_progress`) so may be we could do it once and for all?
In patch set 5 I updated connector.py to allow for blocking calls and utilized the TaskMonitor.

Good points about a blocking call in the above 2 comments. And the specific examples/use-cases are very helpful. Let me think about these some more...

It seems we lose both the final response and resource identifier that should be supplied with 202 response. Here's what Redfish says:

    Once the operation has completed, the Task Monitor shall 
    return a the appropriate status code ( OK 200 for most operations, 
    Created 201 for POST to create a resource) and include the headers 
    and response body of the initial operation, as if it had completed 
    synchronously. If the initial operation resulted in an error, the body 
    of the response shall contain an Error Response.

    The client can continue to get information about the status by directly 
    querying the Task resource using the resource identifier returned in the 
    body of the 202 (Accepted) response.

May be we should return something else beyond `bool`?
In patch set 5 I added a `response` property to get the response.

Good point about losing the response once the operation has completed. Maybe still return a boolean for `in_progress`, but also save the response and have another method/property that the returns the response?

I agree there's an ascetic disadvantage compared to using something opaque.  I think the "conflicting timestamp" argument is ... less compelling.

The main reason we're tied to using timestamps is sorting in the container?versions listings - the object written into the DB have the inverse of the timestamp in the name so our existing db index can easily return all versions in most recent to oldest order.

So the name in the listing has to include the timestamp - if we use just the opaque identifier we loose ordering.  If tried to use a timestamp for ordering AND opaque identifier - we'd have to do a lookup.

The ascetic disadvantage seems worth the benefit of the elegant and efficient implementation.
the version is used in the object name, so having the inversed timestamp helps with listing the objects in the order they were versioned.

It's a little sneaky...

Container sync uses an internal client with symlink in the pipeline to fetch data, then forwards all of that on to the remote cluster. As a result, it'll have the client-facing header in the request -- previously it would be ignored, we'd only look at the client-facing etag header, and we'd need to wait for the target to get synced so validation would pass. Now we just move the headers over and call it good.

Fortunately, only container sync can set the override flag (at least, currently), so we should be fairly confident that the header will be included. It probably would be better to check for the header and raise a 400 if it's missing, though. Follow-up?

so the env override is set on all validated container sync requests... and the container sync client is already doing ?symlink=get in the source cluster - I validated it's forwarding the response headers

the symlink-target header will have already transfered to sysmeta, the etag is coming from the x-target-symlink-etag header, the content-type will pass through and the bytes will blow up if missing

docker/fluentd/Dockerfile.j2.message: if you read both out loud then you might discover there is something wrong about the situation - is it ruby 2.3 or is it not then? if td-agent provides ruby, then why does it fail on fluentd? more questions than answers...
Is the problem that we install td-agent, then these plugins pull in fluentd via deps? Who knows what we end up running...

td-agent 2 is old stable and it comes with -embedded- ruby 2.1.

The latest release of fluentd[1] is 1.9.0 which requires ruby >= 2.4. The last fluentd[2] release which supports ruby < 2.4 is 1.8.1.

For faraday[3][4] which is required by fluent-plugin-elasticsearch, the latest release which supports ruby < 2.3 is 0.15.4.

So if we do not prefer upgrading td-agent, we need to pin the versions of fluentd and faraday.

I will test debian and centos later.

[1] https://rubygems.org/gems/fluentd/
[2] https://rubygems.org/gems/fluentd/versions/1.8.1
[3] https://rubygems.org/gems/faraday/versions/0.15.4
[4] https://rubygems.org/gems/faraday/versions/0.16.0

gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drive.message:
A couple of questions. First is why did you need to move this call to here? The call to _build_endpoint)_neutron_details is made before the call to _build_endpoint_gbp_detail, so the info['fixed_ips'] is already populated by the time it's used. This to me ruins the pattern of queries first, then build later.

Second is more of a nit: why bother changing info['ip_info'] instead of using just info (i.e. the way the current code does it, which is consistent throughout)?

The idea here is that if this fixed_ips info is going to be used by multiple calls (in this case its _build_endpoint_neutron_details() and _build_endpoint_gbp_details()) later on then we just build it once and put it in the info then those 2 calls can just access it directly. We already have pattern like this being present.  info['ext_net_info'] is one example.

My personal opinion about the 2nd comment is that I would rather make it clear about what the parameter is intended to do instead of just passing a big glob which contains everything. By looking at the other APIs, quite a few of them actually require multiple fields in the info glob so passing info directly does makes sense. And I suspect ppl just followed suit when new API is needed that's why we see a pattern like that. Having said this, I'm flexible here so if strongly thinks this is needed then I can change it np.

I don't feel super-strong about this, but my instinct would be to add the fixed IPs parameter to the _build_endpoing_gbp_details, grabbing it from where it's populated.

I see the point of having a clean API with explicit parameters, but to me in this case it's just as readable if there's a blob created with all the state, and then that same blob is used by a bunch of related methods, each of which need some pieces of it. I guess I think we should just strive to have consistency - if we want explicit parameters, then I'd recommend a separate patch that addresses that change.

1. We have a pattern like that already though, info['port_info'] is one example. 
2. ok will change np.

This is more of a style nit: I would just move this into the _build_host_snat_ips method, since these lists aren't used anywhere else. You would only need to add the "details" parameter to the _build_host_sant_ips call.
Can this ever have duplicates (i.e. should this be turned into a set)?
By checking the code again, for each external network there should only be one SNAT port per host so there should be no duplicate here. Let me know if I'm mistaken then.

I don't like that the comment says "query" but _build_fixed_ips does not do a query. 

I also don't see why you needed to move the call to _build_fixed_ips from where it was in _build_endpoint_neutron_details up to here with the queries. Instead, you could pass neutron_details to _build__build_endpopint_gbp_details, which could then pass it to _build_host_snat_ips where its needed.
I think I see your point now. You are saying query v.s. build. In that case I'm ok to move it back to where it was originally built then. Thx.

will change the comment accordingly.

fixed_ips is needed now in both _build_endpoint_neutron_details() and _build_endpoint_gbp_details() that's why I moved it here. We do the same thing for info['port_info'] so in my opinion we are now being consistent. We currently don't have a pattern of passing what's built in one detail (like _build_endpoint_neutron_details) to another so.

I think you should just pass details, and let it pick what it needs, like above.

Also, please try and match the indenting style used throughout this code. If the parameters don't all fit on the line with the function name, don't put any of them on that line, and start the 1st param indented 4 spaces in.

details is passed to _build_host_snat_ips() because that API requires multiple fields inside the details. In this case, _build_ipms() only needs the snat_ips field so I only passed what's needed. But if you feel strongly about this one then I can change it np.

For the indenting style, I've seen this pattern being used throughout our gbp code base though.

It will work as expected. We take the resource_tags, as the "pattern", and trying to match it to the corresponding set from port.tags collection. Even if port.tags have some extra items, that doesn't hurt us:

    >>> tags = set(['a', 'b', 'c'])
    >>> port1_tags = set(['a', 'd'])
    >>> port2_tags = set(['d', 'e'])
    >>> port3_tags = set([])
    >>> port4_tags = set(['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'])
    >>> for p in (port1_tags, port2_tags, port3_tags, port4_tags):
    ...     print(tags.difference(p))
    ... 
    {'b', 'c'}
    {'a', 'b', 'c'}
    {'a', 'b', 'c'}
    set()

Let's clarify than. We remove the port ONLY if it doesn't have ALL the tags defined in resource_tags config option, right?

Because, it's different situation we have here.

In case of neutron client, if we try to remove nonexistsent port, there will be PortNotFoundClient exception thrown, so that we continue the loop (because of line 443, where we catch NeutronClientException, which is a base class for all neutron client exceptions).

In case of openstacksdk, there will be nothing. no result, no exception, for nonexistent port. So we cannot say if it succeed or not. By breaking the loop based on assumption, that it was deleted is a false positive, and we don't have certainty that proper port from existing_ports collection was deleted or not.

zuul/executor/client.py.message: Perhaps create a build_worker variable similarly to the job one above so that the rest of the code doesn't reference a __ private attribute?
The exact same variable is also used already by cancelRunningBuild and in some other places which I didn't want to refactor.

iirc this is used to indicate the build has started and thus can be aborted. Why not naming this attribute started then? Or add a started property to the build object that check for the __gearman_worker

This attribute must be gearman_worker as this is not only used to determine if the build has started but also to which executor stop jobs need to be sent. So gearman_worker really is correct. What we could do however is to remove this variable completely and use build.worker.name directly which contains the same information anyway. (but maybe in a different change as this is an unrelated refactoring?)

zuul/executor/server.py.message:
I think this may introduce a race. getJobData() always looks at the last entry of the gearman Job's data list. The gear lib simply appends each WORK_DATA packet that it receives to this list.

What this means is if the executor client receives the previous WORK_DATA with worker_hostname in it then receives this WORK_DATA with url in it before processing the first WORK_DATA response the client will only see the url work data and not see the worker_hostname data. It will then fail in Worker.updateFromData().

To address this I think we can simply continue to provide the old data here as well then the most recent WORK_DATA entry will include as much info as possible.
